title: Is an Omni-God's Existence Improbable?
description:
Dr. Michael Huemer is a philosophy professor at the University of Colorado, Boulder. Several months ago he published a blog post (linked below) arguing that limited theism is more probable than omni-theism.

Link to Dr. Huemer's blog post:
https://fakenous.substack.com/p/the-probability-of-god

I invited on Dr. Nevin Climenhaga, a professor of philosophy at Texas A&M University, to critique Dr. Huemer's arguments.

0:00 Intro to Huemer's Case
0:24 Metaphysical impossibility of Infinite Attributes
5:56 Prior Probability Decay for Unbounded Magnitudes
8:41 Why Simplicity Doesn‚Äôt Favor Omnipotence
10:23 Problem of Evil Favors Limited Theism Over Omni-Theism
14:08 Climenhaga's Response to Huemer on Infinity
30:56 Climenhaga's Response to Huemer on Prior Probability
47:02 Climenhaga's Response to Huemer on Evil
1:00:00 Huemer's Concluding Thoughts
1:01:13 Climenhaga's Concluding Thoughts

title: Old Testament Sexual Violence: A Scholarly Discussion
description:
What do you do with commands in scripture attributed to God that seem to condone sexual violence toward women? This is a tough topic to discuss and what you‚Äôll hear in this video may be triggering or inappropriate for some viewers, so please be cautious when listening. I invited two Christian scholars with different perspectives to discuss this issue. The first is Dr. Randal Rauser, author of the book Jesus Loves Canaanites. The second is Dr. David Lamb, author of the book God Behaving Badly. The links to both books are below. 

In this discussion we‚Äôll focus on two passages Deuteronomy 21:10-14 and Deuteronomy 22:22-29.

title: The Gospel Isn‚Äôt What You Think It Is
description:
Christians have missed what the gospel is really about. It is not first and foremost about your sins. Somewhere along the way we reduced the gospel to ‚Äúthe plan of salvation.‚Äù It‚Äôs not. So what is the gospel then? My guest, Dr. Matthew Bates explains.

title: The Problem of EXCESSIVE Pointless Evil
description:
Most theists think that God can allow some evil, so long as there is a point to doing so. But you might be surprised to hear that some theists think it's OK for God to allow pointless evil too! In this video, Dr. Klaas Kraay joins me to explain why Dr. William Hasker thinks that God has to allow pointless evil, and you'll hear an argument for atheism that says that even if Hasker is right, a new problem of evil arises- the problem of too much pointless evil in the world.

This interview was recorded in person at the 2023 SCP conference at Calvin University. I want to thank my patrons and other financial supporters for fully funding this trip!

Please consider becoming a patron. Just go to https://www.patreon.com/theanalyticchristian

If you have questions or suggestions for future interviews, email me at theanalyticchristian@gmail.com

title: Is Free Will Compatible With Determinism?
description:
In this discussion I'm joined by Dr. Taylor Cyr and Dr. Justin Capes. Both believe humans have free will. However, they differ on the question of whether free will is compatible with determinism. Dr. Cyr is a compatibilist. Dr. Capes is an incompatibilist. In this discussion, they give the most up to date arguments and objections on this topic. 

Check out my Playlist on Free Will
https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLlVH-ThCazKkPhJEIKq3_BkYGGl8xzhTX&si=O7zHaXJShNBuPkGO

For more on Dr. Taylor Cyr check out his website linked below.
https://taylorwcyr.com/

For more on Dr. Justin Capes check out his website linked below.
https://www.justincapes.com/

title: Profs Reveal the SECRETS to Publishing in Philosophy
description:
Struggling to get your philosophy paper published? You're not alone! In this video, we crack the code with two philosophy professors- Dr. Liz Jackson and Dr. Justin Mooney. They share their insider tips and secrets on getting your work accepted by top journals. Learn what editors are looking for, how to navigate the peer review process, and how to increase your chances of publication. Whether you're a graduate student, early career researcher, or seasoned philosopher, this video has valuable insights to help you see your work in print.


0:00 Intro
6:40 Should I publish?
16:27 When should I publish?
21:32 When my paper ready to submit?
28:54 How do I submit a paper?
36:01 How do I pick a journal?
44:44 Top 20 philosophy journals
59:44 How long does it take to publish?
1:04:21 How can I publish before going on the job market?
1:09:49 What if my paper is rejected?
1:16:58 How do I handle an R&R?
1:25:53 Q&A

Link to slides:
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vS3WNpE51HMef_jzsY_aEVuJAW57Q_bAKLaA7neZZTRHcoUNtb0G9KxMpeW4fIygunh2vqjGV4Sob-Y/pub?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000

#philosophy_point  #academicpublishing #phdlife #research #philosophyofeducation #continentalphilosophy #analyticphilosophy

title: The SCARIEST Argument for Skepticism
description:
This video features an in-depth discussion led by a professional epistemologist, Dr. Kevin McCain, on the topic of skepticism, particularly external world skepticism initiated by Rene Descartes' idea of being deceived by an evil demon. The conversation delves into philosophical skepticism, its implications, and different responses to skepticism including reliabilism, sensitivity accounts, contextualism, the Moorean approach, hinge propositions, and inference to the best explanation, with a particular focus on demonstrating why the external world hypothesis is superior to skeptical alternatives like Descartes' Demon. The dialogue concludes by addressing four objections to the inference to the best explanation response.

00:00 Intro
00:55 What is Skepticism?
02:03 Why Should We Care About Skeptical Scenarios?
05:12 Explaining Descartes' Demon Thought Experiment
08:26 Seven Responses to Descartes' Demon
19:35 Inference to the Best Explanation Response
24:27 Addressing Four Objections to Inference to the Best Explanation
40:21 Concluding Thoughts and Further Resources

For Dr. McCain's book "Evidentialism & Epistemic Justification" click the link below.
https://www.routledge.com/Evidentialism-and-Epistemic-Justification/McCain/p/book/9781138657335

For Dr. McCain's book "Epistemology: 50 Puzzles, Paradoxes, and Thought Experiments" click the link below.
https://www.routledge.com/Epistemology-50-Puzzles-Paradoxes-and-Thought-Experiments/McCain/p/book/9780367638726

title: NEW Evidence for GOD You Don't Want to Miss
description:
I'm joined by Dr. Brian Cutter, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame. We discuss a paper he co-authored  titled, "The Problem of Nomological Harmony" published in the prestigious journal Nous. 

Free access to paper: https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/nous.12463

Timestamps
0:00 Intro

title: How Philosophy Can Help You Live a Meaningful Life (Dr. Paul Blaschko)

title: Does Moral Knowledge Prove God? (Dustin Crummett vs. Louise Antony)
description:
Dr. Dustin Crummett is a professor of philosophy at the University of Washington Tacoma and Seattle Pacific University. Dustin has co-authored a paper with Dr. Philip Swenson defending an argument from God based on moral knowledge. Here's the link to the paper.

https://philarchive.org/archive/CRUGAM

Dr. Louise Antony is a professor of philosophy at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She is critical of arguments for God from moral knowledge. To explore her critique in more depth, check out her written debate with Dr. Mark Linville in the book, "Contemporary Debates in Philosophy of Religion." Here's the link to the book.

https://www.amazon.com/Contemporary-Debates-Philosophy-Religion-Peterson/dp/1119028450/ref=pd_lpo_1?pd_rd_w=sdZr0&content-id=amzn1.sym.116f529c-aa4d-4763-b2b6-4d614ec7dc00&pf_rd_p=116f529c-aa4d-4763-b2b6-4d614ec7dc00&pf_rd_r=KRCJKZQ8VACKTZJMXVN7&pd_rd_wg=c7QEo&pd_rd_r=9ac92097-0e65-4f71-a05c-f2ebc77d4717&pd_rd_i=1119028450&psc=1

#philosophy #apologetics 

I'm grateful for feedback from Dr. Andrew Moon, Dr. Liz Jackson, and Dr. Justin Mooney on the script.

title: Theism or Panpsychism: Which Better Explains Consciousness?
description:
Dr. Brian Cutter is a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame. His main area of research is the philosophy of mind. He is a theist and has a forthcoming paper defending an argument for theism from psychophysical harmony. Here's a link to his paper.
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1GaT_ynEIIYO_FaUmado_1nz3dKj5Cj1L/view

For more on Dr. Cutter, check out his website linked below.
https://sites.google.com/site/cutterbc/home

Dr. Philip Goff is a professor of philosophy at Durham University. His main area of research is the philosophy of mind. He is a panpsychist and has several papers defending the view. For a nice introduction, check out this article from Scientific American.
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/does-consciousness-pervade-the-universe/

For more on Dr. Goff, check out his website linked below.
https://www.philipgoffphilosophy.com/

title: The MOST Overused Objection to Arguments for God (Dr. Greg Ganssle)
description:
00:00 Introduction

03:51 General form of a theistic argument that gets labeled as ‚Äúgod of the gaps‚Äù

06:24 Where is the ‚Äúgap‚Äù in this argument?

08:16 The conditional premise used to justify Premise 1

14:10 Scientific advances that may make this argument unsuccessful

23:56 Divine agency expectations and supernatural explanations

28:15 Arguments in support of Conditional (1d)

32:43 Forms of two arguments that are immune to the shrinking gap objection

40:23 Q&A

56:14 Summary and Conclusion

Dr. Greg Ganssle is a professor of philosophy at Biola University, and published an essay critiquing the "God of the Gaps" objection in the Blackwell Companion to Science and Christianity. 

Link to book: https://www.amazon.com/Blackwell-Companion-Science-Christianity/dp/1444335715#:~:text=Bringing%20together%20some%20of%20the,intersection%20of%20science%20and%20Christianity.

Link to Dr. Gannsle's publications: https://www.biola.edu/directory/people/greg-ganssle

title: Dynamic vs. Static Views of Heaven (Dr. Eric Silverman)
description:
0:00 Intro

10:05 Why do some philosophers and theologians hold to the static view?

19:51 What are the three subtypes of the dynamic view of heaven?

21:55 What advantages does the dynamic view have over the static view?

27:29 Response to Richard Dawkins‚Äô ‚ÄúHeaven is boring‚Äù objection

The dynamic view of heaven is the view that heaven is a place or state of existence where moral, aesthetic, epistemological, relational, and other changes or progress takes place. The static view of heaven is the view that none of those changes or progress takes place. In this interview, Dr. Eric Silverman critiques arguments for the static view, and argues the dynamic view is superior.

This interview is a summary of Dr. Silverman's chapter in the book, Paradise Understood, linked below.
https://www.amazon.com/Paradise-Understood-Philosophical-Essays-Heaven-ebook/dp/B06XNWQ98G/ref=sr_1_1?crid=7HF604FQK9PK&keywords=paradise+understood+eric+silverman&qid=1655841619&sprefix=paradise+understood+eric+silverman%2Caps%2C78&sr=8-1

title: Is Living A Sinless Life Possible Apart from God‚Äôs Grace? (Dr. Daniel Speak)
description:
In this Ask A Scholar Video Dr. Daniel Speak answers the following question. 
"It seems like there is a tension between some Christian doctrines and libertarian freedom. If humans have libertarian freedom (in the leeway sense), isn‚Äôt it possible for humans to live a sinless life? If the answer is yes, doesn‚Äôt that lead to pelagianism? If the answer is no, why not? One might say ‚Äòbecause we have a certain character that limits the range of options we have to choose from.‚Äô But there‚Äôs a problem with this response. Either we ultimately get to choose our characters or we do not ultimately get to choose our characters. If we ultimately get to choose our characters, then it seems like we could have chosen characters such that we always had the option to refrain from sinning. But if that‚Äôs the case, then we run back into the original worry about pelagianism. On the other hand, if we do not ultimately get to choose our own characters, then how am I morally responsible for sinning due to a character that I did not get to choose?‚Äù

Dr. Speak is a professor of philosophy at Loyola Marymount University. For more on Dr. Speak check out the link below.
https://philpeople.org/profiles/daniel-speak

01:05:38 Question by Justin Mooney: How about responding to the Pelagian worry by saying that being in a certain location is necessary, but not sufficient for being in heaven?

01:06:57 Question by Kito: Does the hyperspace solution face the technology objection?  In principle, we could travel the extra spatial dimension(s).  Seems like any locationalism solution faces the objection. 

01:07:38 Question from Hayden Stephan

01:08:24 Question from Joseph Aggs: Could the hyperspace theory address trinitarian puzzles?  Like the persons of God exist in three dimensions but are Unitarian in nature?

Cruz Davis is a PhD candidate at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. In a forthcoming paper he presents the "Problem of the Ascension of Jesus" and then evaluates various solutions. Here are some of the questions we'll be discussing. If Jesus was *physically* raised from the dead, where is his body now?  If you say it's in heaven, does that mean heaven has a spatial location? If yes, does that mean it's theoretically possible to reach heaven if we just had enough advanced technology? If no, then how can Jesus have a physical resurrection body?

For more from Cruz Davis, check out his philpapers page linked below.

title: How to Interpret Rom 1:18-20 Charitably (Dr. Randal Rauser)
description:
In Romans 1:18-20 (NASB), Paul writes, 
"For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of people who suppress truth in unrighteousness, because that which is known about God is evident within them; for God made it evident to them. For since the creation of the world, His invisible attributes, that is, His eternal power and divine nature have been clearly perceived, being understood by what has been made, so that they are without excuse." 

Does this text mean every single non-believer is resistant in their non-belief? In this video, Dr. Rauser provides several reasons to think the answer is no.

There‚Äôs a sorties series from no change between pre and post disassembly watch (same parts and arrangement) to lots of change between pre and post resurrection person (different parts and arrangement).  Suppose there‚Äôs no sharp cut-off or vagueness in the sorites series.  Since watches can survive dis/reassembly, it follows that persons can be resurrected. 

55:03 Question #2 ‚Äì Does your model assume that a particle‚Äôs history can be tracked? That it is possible to give to a particle a name X and track the entire history of where X was?

Scripture teaches that there will be a general resurrection of the dead. In this interview, Dr. Justin Mooney joins me to discuss he updated version of the resurrection by reassembly model. To explore this model in more depth, check out his paper linked below.

title: Exploring 5 Models of the Resurrection (Dr. Eric Yang)
description:
0:00 Introduction

0:51 the book: An Introduction to Christian Philosophical Theology

01:18 Describe what you mean by ‚Äúresurrection.‚Äù

02:41 What are some views on the nature of human persons?

05:07 What is the difference between a two-stage and a three-stage view of the resurrection?

08:00 Will our resurrected body be numerically identical to our body at death?  What are some reasons to think ‚Äúyes?‚Äù What are some reasons to think ‚Äúno‚Äù?

13:51 Five models of the resurrection of the dead

14:18 What is the resurrection by reassembly model?

23:08 What is the body snatching model?

28:14 What is the falling elevator model?

36:21 What is anti-criterialism account?

43:16 What is the hypertime model?

50:15 Comment #1: Going back to the point about Christ‚Äôs resurrection as a model of ours, Christ‚Äôs resurrection wasn‚Äôt hyper-temporal. 

52:44 How would you like to conclude our discussion?

56:53 Question #1: Tangential, but 1 Cor 15:38-40 suggests that every human (righteous or not) is going to receive an imperishable body by virtue of belonging to humankind.  Does that contradict annihilationism?



Traditional Christianity teaches that when Christ returns, our bodies will be raised from the dead. But how is resurrection of the same body even possible? In this interview with Dr. Eric Yang, we discuss several models of resurrection including:

- resurrection by reassembly
- body-snatching view
- falling-elevator account
- anti-criterialism
- hypertime account

For more, check out Chapter 6 of Dr. Yang's book, "An Introduction to Christian Philosophical Theology" linked below.

title: A Defense of the Evolutionary Argument Against Naturalism (Dr. Andrew Moon)
description:
0:00 Introduction

01:14 What got you interested in the evolutionary argument against naturalism?

02:47 What is the Evolutionary Argument against Naturalism (EAAN)?

05:03 What are the specific premises and conclusion of EAAN?

11:40 Definition of terms in order to understand the Defense of Premise 1 [P(R|N&E) is low]: Materialism, Mental Properties, Content Properties, NP, Reductive Materialism, Non-reductive materialism

13:57 How does Plantinga defend premise 1 [P(R|N&E) is low]?

15:06 Defense of Premise 1: what follows from non-reductive materialism?

19:30 Defense of Premise 1: what happens if reductive materialism is true?

27:59 Objection to Premise 1: But doesn‚Äôt it still seem like having faculties that produce true beliefs are more likely to make a creature survive?

32:53 Defense of Premise 2: Anyone who accepts (believes) N&E and see that [P(R|N&E) is low has a defeater for R.

37:04 Objection 1 to EAAN: EAAN depends on externalism

43:17 Objection 2 to EAAN: EAAN is self-defeating

47:50 Question #1: if the naturalist holds a concept of truth other than the correspondentist one (like Putnam‚Äôs internal realism), does the EAAN still work against him? Greetings from Brazil!

49:50 Question #1 follow-up: Does the argument presuppose correspondence theory of truth?

50:20  Question #2: Dr. Moon, do you think that if the probability of our cognitive faculties being reliable is inscrutable, the argument would still work?

52:44 Question #3: What is the conditional objection aka objection 3?

57:43 Question #4: What do you say about Richard Swinburne‚Äôs objections to Plantinga‚Äôs argument?

58:31 Question #5: Are there any books or resources to learn about the discussion of mind/soul, neuroscience and materialism that you‚Äôd recommend to mortals like me?

59:47 Question #6: Could a bias towards simplicity solve the problem? A possible world where belief contents are randomly associated with neurological states (i.e. if you change a single, or a single atom in a neuron or environment, you don‚Äôt automatically generate a random belief).

01:04:34 Question #7: Does this argument work the same if someone holds to dualism, idealism or Thomism?

01:07:04 Question #8: Why do the content propositions need to be selected for because of their true in order for the cognitive faculties to be reliable?  Isn‚Äôt it enough that they supervene on things which are selected for?

01:08:38 Question #9: Do you think evolutionary debunking arguments against moral realism that presupposes naturalism has a self-defeating argument?

01:10:24 Question #10: Does Plantinga think that we are left with a certain choice to make in rejecting either naturalism, evolution or both?

01:11:52 Question #11: What do you think of the following argument? 1. Our cognitive faculties are generally unreliable. 2. (1) is more expected given Naturalism rather than Theism. 3. So, (1) is evidence for N. 

In this interview, Dr. Andrew Moon will summarize Plantinga's Evolutionary Argument Against Naturalism (EAAN), then respond to some objections. For a short animated summary of the argument, check out the video linked below.

To go more in depth, check out Dr. Moon's recent paper, "Global Debunking Arguments" linked below.

title: Avoiding TOO MUCH Skepticism (Dr. John DePoe)
description:
0:00 Introduction

01:10 What is the evidential argument from evil?

07:33 How does the skeptical theist respond to this argument?

12:55 What are some challenges to skeptical theism?

15:41 What do you try to show in this paper? Answer: Hopefully use the theoretical goods of skeptical theism to respond to the problem of evil but at the same time not letting in all these other forms of skepticism

17:22 Negative skeptical theism

19:04 Positive skeptical theism

21:10 Similarity between positive and negative skeptical theism

21:23 Difference between positive and negative skeptical theism

22:30 Can you elaborate a bit on Bergmann‚Äôs negative skeptical theism view?

26:43 Recap the positive skeptical theism view

28:51 What are two second-order reasons God may have for creating a world with seemingly gratuitous evils?

29:05 First second-order reason: epistemic distance

32:19 Second second-order reason: this world allows humans to bring about the greatest acts of love and compassion

41:53 Challenge to the second second-order reason: if someone believes no evil is truly gratuitous due to skeptical theism, does it remove the motivation for that person to intervene in evil to show love and compassion

45:17 Why do you think positive skeptical theism is the better account?

52:44 The Bayesian Comparison between Positive and Negative Skeptical Theism

59:40 How would you like to conclude this discussion?

A common objection to skeptical theism is that if applied consistently it leads one to be skeptical of things we do in fact know about the external world and morality. title: Foreknowledge & Free Will
description:
In this video I summarize an argument that aims to show that divine foreknowledge precludes human freedom. I then summarize six responses to the argument. 

Here is a form of the argument that does not rely on the transfer principle.
1. God believed 1,000 years ago that I would raise my hand at t.
2. If P1 and I am free not to raise my hand at t, then it is my power to do something such that, were I to do it, either (i) God would have had at least one different belief 1,000 years ago, or (ii) God would have had at least one false belief 1,000 years ago.
3. It is not in my power to do something such that, were I to do it, (i) God would have had at least one different belief 1,000 years ago, or (ii) God would have had at least one false belief 1,000 years ago. 
4. Therefore, I am not free to raise my hand at t.

To explore this argument in more depth, check out the argument map I've created linked below, as well as the link to my interview with Dr. Taylor Cyr.
https://youtu.be/_XoVp1tKrGU
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1-tIBA0FP8CiWmchH8zLW0CvHrgr2ri_q1bRk4XMGSEI/present?fbclid=IwAR2WjpsfsLwtAw3wrJEWL2PrRvVo5slsByJobHIVxfqqOLRcRyM8U8sN30o&slide=id.gf0115c6564_0_161

title: 5 Responses to "The Problem of No Best World" (Dr. Klaas Kraay)
description:
If there is no best possible world, then for any world God picked to actualize, God could have picked a better one. But if God could have picked a better one, then it seems that God could have performed a better action. And if God could have performed a better action, then God could have been better. But how can God be better if God is essentially unsurpassable (a.k.a. "the greatest conceivable being"). This is a serious challenge to theism, and in this video Dr. Kraay offers five responses to this argument. 

To read more about this topic, check out Dr. Kraay's paper linked below.
https://people.ryerson.ca/kraay/Documents/2010Companion.pdf

To see Dr. Kraay's defense of the view that there is a best possible world, and it is a multiverse, check out my interview linked below.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kyXDlyI0Swg&t=276s

Dr. Anne Jeffrey is a professor of philosophy at Baylor University. In my previous interview, we discussed the explanatory role God plays in moral normativity and moral epistemology. In this interview Dr. Jeffrey and I will discuss four arguments that God plays a significant explanatory role in moral motivation. The first of these four arguments is based on a forthcoming paper by Dr. Jeffrey titled, "Divine Friendship and Moral Motivation."

title: Free Will Skepticism & Christian Theology (Dr. Derk Pereboom)
description:
Dr. Pereboom is a professor of philosophy at Cornell. One of his main areas of research is on free will and moral responsibility. Interestingly, Dr. Pereboom thinks that humans do not have free will. In this interview I will ask Dr. Pereboom the following questions:
1. What is your view of human freedom?
2. What are some reasons to think this view is true?
3. What are some objections to your view, and how do you respond?
4. What are the implications of this view for Christian theology? 

For more on Dr. Pereboom check out his website linked below.
https://www.derk-pereboom.net/

Check out my interview with Dr. Taylor Cyr offering a basic introduction to the topic of free will.

title: Defusing the Common Sense Problem of Evil (Dr. Chris Tweedt)
description:
Dr. Alvin Plantinga has stated that "the best version of the atheological case from evil" is the non-inferential version. This version is called, "the common sense problem of evil." It poses a challenge for skeptical theism because it avoids a "noseeum" inference. In this interview, Dr. Chris Tweedt reformulates a principle used by skeptical theists and argues that this principle prevents anyone from having any justification (even non-inferential) for the belief that there is gratuitous evil.

This interview is based on Dr. Tweedt's paper linked below.
https://philarchive.org/archive/TWEDTC

For more from Dr. Tweedt, check out his website
https://christweedt.com/

title: What Makes Religious Commitment Rational? (Dr. Brian Ballard)
description:
In this interview we discuss Dr. Ballard's paper, "The rationality of faith and the benefits of religion." Here's an excerpt from the abstract: "Religions don't simply make claims about the world, they also offer existential resources... for dealing with human problems, such as the need for meaning, love, identity, and personal growth...My thesis is that the extent to which it is good for a certain religion to be true is relevant to the epistemic (rather than merely pragmatic) rationality of faith in that religion."

You can read the paper by going to Dr. Ballard's website linked below.
https://www.brianscottballard.com/

He also has a simplified version of the paper on his apologetics website.

title: An Emotionally Realistic View of Paradise (Dr. Adam Pelser)
description:
Many believe that life in heaven will be characterized by perfect joy. One common objection to this view is that if anyone will be suffering in hell, then the inhabitants of heaven either will experience certain negative emotions about those in hell, thus rendering their heavenly joy imperfect, or they won‚Äôt, thus revealing them to be unloving or otherwise deficient. In this interview Dr. Adam Pelser argues that it is plausible that the inhabitants of heaven will experience some negative emotions‚Äîfor example, heavenly sadness‚Äîabout the suffering of those in hell and about past evils, without such emotions undermining their perfect heavenly joy.

I did a previous interview on this topic with Dr. Eric Yang, where he outlined four alternative solutions to this problem. You can check it out here.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xcbl7xxXzxs

Dr. Pelser is Professor of Philosophy at the U.S. Air Force Academy. For more from Dr. Pelser, check out his website.
https://www.adampelser.com/

title: Does the NT Teach that Jesus is Truly Divine?
description:
Dr. Dale Tuggy (left) and Dr. Andrew Loke (right) join me to discuss the question, "Does the New Testament Teach that Jesus is Truly Divine?" Dr. Tuggy says the answer is "No" while Dr. Andrew Loke says the answer is "Yes." The format of this debate will be as follows:

title: Interpreting Scripture in Light of Our Moral Intuitions (Dr. Randal Rauser)
description:
How should Christians interpret passages of scripture that violate our most basic moral intuitions? Passages like Deuteronomy 7, 20, and Joshua 1-12 that portray God as commanding and aiding the Israelites to brutally annihilate the Canaanites, young and old, men and women. Dr. Randal Rauser recently authored what I consider to be the best book on this topic, "Jesus Loves Canaanites". In this interview we summarize the major points of the book, focusing specifically on Rauser's critique of Dr. Paul Copan's and Dr. Matthew Flannagan's arguments, and Rauser's defense of what he calls "Providential Errancy."

I highly encourage you to read Rauser's book for yourself. It's linked below.
https://www.amazon.com/Jesus-Loves-Canaanites-Biblical-Intuition/dp/1775046249/ref=sr_1_1?crid=31GDXKPF1Y6T7&dchild=1&keywords=jesus+loves+canaanites&qid=1627354701&sprefix=jesus+loves+can%2Caps%2C182&sr=8-1

title: A Circular Defense of Phenomenal Conservatism (Dr. Chris Tucker)
description:
This week's question was, "I have a concern with Phenomenal Conservatism (PC). This concern is meta-justificatory. I‚Äôm not sure that seemings are capable of conferring justification. This is due to the fact that, by PC's own admission, they only confer prima facie justifcation meaning that they do not necessarily connect with truth. Something could seem to be true and yet fail to be true. But, if that is the case, then why think that they usually connect with truth? Why think that they ever do? You can't appeal to the fact that it seems that seemings usually connect to truth on pain of circularity. But then what is the justification for thinking that a seeming is an indication of truth?‚Äù

Dr. Chris Tucker is a professor of philosophy at William & Mary. Click the link below to watch my interview with Dr. Tucker on the use of phenomenal conservatism in religious epistemology.
https://youtu.be/LgBlLnT3h38

title: The Kenotic Theory of God becoming Human (Dr. Stephen T. Davis)
description:
I'm joined by emeritus professor of philosophy, Dr. Stephen T. Davis to offer a defense of kenotic christology. The core idea of kenotic christology is that in the incarnation,  Jesus Christ "emptied himself" (Phil 2:7)  by temporarily giving up those divine properties that are inconsistent with being truly human while retaining sufficient divine properties to remain truly divine. In this interview, Dr. Davis will lay out some of the metaphysics behind this view, biblical support for it, and he'll respond to four of the most common objections. 

To explore this topic in more detail, check out Dr. Davis' chapter, "The metaphysics of kenosis" in the book, The Metaphysics of Incarnation linked below.
https://bit.ly/metaphysicsofincarnation

title: Exploring the Mind-Body Problem (Dr. Tomas Bogardus)
description:
In this interview, Dr. Tomas Bogardus will first summarize some of the views on the mind-body problem, then offer three arguments for dualism. This includes an argument from knowledge, an argument from personal identity, and an argument from "undefeated dualism."

For a robust defense of the argument from undefeated dualism, check out Dr. Bogardus' paper, "Undefeated Dualism" at his website linked below.
https://sites.google.com/site/tbogardus/

If you'd like to see how dualism is strong evidence for the existence of God, check out my other interview with Dr. Bogardus linked below.
https://youtu.be/xY6hErf6TBg

Please consider supporting me on Patreon. Just go to https://www.patreon.com/theanalyticchristian

For more resources on Christian philosophy & theology, go to https://www.theanalyticchristian.com

title: Embracing the Contradiction of Christ's Incarnation (Dr. Jc Beall)
description:
In this interview I'm joined by Dr. Jc Beall, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame. He will defend the view that Christ is a contradictory being. By that he means that Christ is a being of whom some claims are both true and false.

To explore Dr. Beall's view in more detail, check out his new book published by Oxford University Press, "The Contradictory Christ."
https://www.amazon.com/Contradictory-Christ-Studies-Analytic-Theology/dp/0198852363

For a different perspective on the incarnation, check out my interview with Dr. Tim Pawl. 
https://youtu.be/3BK_-LUamwY

title: 4 Responses to the "Problem of Eternal Separation" (Dr. Eric Yang)
description:
Can the residents of heaven be happy while knowing their loved one is suffering in hell? It seems their eternal separation from their loved one would keep them from truly experiencing the joy of heaven. This has been called "The Problem of Eternal Separation." In this interview I'm joined by Dr. Eric Yang, a professor of Philosophy at Santa Clara University. He will explain and critique two traditional responses to this problem, namely the Aquinas/Edwards view, and the "Partial Amnesia" view. Then, he will lay out two new responses that he has developed.

You can read Dr. Yang's paper here
https://1d67b515-a1e8-4df8-9572-56c4d8a0139c.filesusr.com/ugd/74d1de_325f0f35020a4c45b2f9950e31a994d2.pdf

For more on Dr. Yang check out his website
https://www.erictyang.com/

Please consider supporting me on patreon. Go to
http://www.patreon.com/theanalyticchristian

For more resources on Christian philosophy and theology, go to
http://www.theanalyticchristian.com

title: A Defense of Postmortem Opportunity (Dr. James Beilby)
description:
0:00 Introduction

0:55 Tell us about your background and how you got interested in the topic of Postmortem opportunity?

2:52 Who do you have in mind when you say unevangelized and pseudo evangelized?

8:21 What is the problem of the unevangelized/pseudo evangelized?

11:06 The Soteriological Problem of Evil

14:17 What are some of the traditional responses to this problem?

19:27 What is your response to the Soteriological Problem of Evil?

31:03 What is your theological argument for Postmortem Opportunity?

39:42 What do you think are some of the strongest Scriptural objections to postmortem opportunity and how do you respond?

48:04 What are the strongest theological objections to postmortem opportunity and how do you respond?

50:54 Question #1: Why does God command us to evangelize, given that God also provides postmortem opportunity?

57:44 What do you think is some of the strongest scriptural evidence for postmortem opportunity?

01:05:08 Question #2: Would everyone be given a postmortem opportunity?  Even those who received the gospel and actively rejected it?

01:07:35 Question #3: of all the things ‚Äúhell‚Äù encompasses, is rehabilitation one of them?

1:10:34 Question #4: Arguably, people will have better evidence for Christianity postmortem than premortem.  But then isn‚Äôt leaving someone unevangelized (and so a candidate for postmortem opportunity) better?

In this interview, I'm joined by Dr. James Beilby, a professor of systematic and philosophical theology at Bethel University. He will be lay out the "soteriological problem of evil" (a.k.a. the problem of the unevangelized/pseudoevangelized), traditional responses to it, and his preferred response to it. He will defend his view both scripturally and theologically.

title: Does God Explain Morality? (Dr. Anne Jeffrey)
description:
In this interview, I'm joined by Dr. Anne Jeffrey, a professor of philosophy at Baylor University. In 2018, her book, God & Morality was published with Cambridge University Press. There are three sections of the book. The first section surveys the philosophical literature on God's role in grounding moral normativity. The second section of the book surveys the philosophical literature on God's role in explaining moral knowledge. Our interview will be a summary of these two sections, and Dr. Jeffrey will explain how "thin theism" does not explain moral normativity and moral knowledge as well as "thick theism."

Here's the link to the Dr. Jeffrey's book- https://www.amazon.com/God-Morality-Elements-Philosophy-Religion/dp/1108469442/ref=sr_1_3?dchild=1&keywords=god+and+morality&qid=1613158960&sr=8-3

http://www.theanalyticchristian.com

title: A Defense of Tradition "Maximalism" vs. "Minimalism" (Dr. Luke Stamps)
description:
In this interview, I'm joined by Dr. Luke Stamps, a professor of theology at the Divinity School of Anderson University. His essay, "Norma Normata: The Role of Tradition in Analytic Theology" was recently published in the T&T Clark Handbook of Analytic Theology. In the essay, Dr. Stamps lays out a theological framework for thinking about the role of ecumenical creeds and councils in analytic theology. Our interview is a summary of major points in his framework.

Here's the link to book where you can find Dr. Stamps essay.
https://www.amazon.com/Clark-Handbook-Analytic-Theology-Handbooks/dp/0567681297

title: How to be a Committed Christian & Truth-Seeker (Dr. Liz Jackson)
description:
In this 10 minute interview, Dr. Liz Jackson answers the following question:

"Can a Christian be a committed Christian and at the same time a committed truth-seeker? The worry is that making a commitment to Christ means becoming closed to the possibility that Christianity is false, which would be a failure of the intellectual virtue of humility."

title: An Actual Sequence Perfect Being Theology (Dr. John Martin Fischer)
description:
In this interview, I'm joined by Dr. John Martin Fischer to explore the possibility of a Perfect Being Theology that does not require humans to have the freedom to do otherwise while retaining moral responsibility. He will then lay out the implications of such a view on both determinism and indeterminism. In the course of the conversation we'll discuss hell, the problem of evil, and Dr. Fischer's proposal for partially open theism.

title: A Christian Response to Religious Debunking Arguments (Dr. Andrew Moon)
description:
In this interview, Dr. Andrew Moon offers a really interesting response to religious debunking arguments. His response is based on what he calls an "epistemically self-promoting proposition." This is a proposition that, when justifiedly believed, gives one a reason to think that one reliably believes it. Andrew will then explain how such a proposition plays a key role in his argument that religious believers can permissibly wield an epistemically circular argument in response to certain debunking arguments.

Check out my previous interview with Andrew arguing that Christian belief can be properly basic
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gOCbOx9-QTQ

Check out Andrew's paper on the topic.
https://philpapers.org/rec/MOOCAQ

title: A Positive Case for Objective Morality (Dr. Eric Sampson)
description:
0:00 Intro
2:35 What is moral realism and why should we care if it‚Äôs true?
5:41 What arguments are there for moral realism?
7:31 What is the Modal Ontological Argument for moral realism?
20:13 What is the Moorean Argument for moral realism?
34:27 What is the companions in guilt argument for moral realism?
45:02 What is David Enoch‚Äôs Argument for moral realism?
58:45 What is Quasi-Realism?
1:01:36 How would you solve the Is-Ought Gap?
1:06:34 Does Enoch‚Äôs argument put pressure on normative facts being inter subjective?
1:08:15 What‚Äôs your view on consequentialism?
1:10:30 Is there any good reason to accept moral subjectivism?
1:12:38 How can we support premise 2 of your Modal Ontological Argument for moral realism?
1:14:08 Non-Cognitivism & Frege-Geach problem
1:17:00 Supervenience
1:17:43 Wrapping Up Discussion

There are two broad strategies one can use to show the truth of moral realism- defense and offense. When playing defense, one tries to show that criticisms of the view do not succeed, while criticisms of alternative positions do succeed. This could be called, "The Argument from Elimination." When playing offense, one tries to give positive reasons in favor of moral realism. In this interview, Dr. Eric Sampson will  play offense by providing four arguments in support of moral realism.

Here is the google doc used in our discussion.
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1MBPYK_UHOoQhEKjR1URok4tO_tXgqCY5wy5pyFzSZDk/edit?usp=sharing

title: Why Theology Is Valuable (Dr. Ryan Mullins)
description:
This week's question was, "Is most theology pure speculation? When we engage in debates on various issues such as the free will defense against the argument from evil, the possible reasons behind divine Hiddenness, or if God can change his mind; all of this is extra-biblical. The Bible is kind of thin when it comes to a lot of theological questions. It‚Äôs got the basics covered, but beyond that we‚Äôre on our own. If the canon is closed and we can‚Äôt expect further revelation, is such speculation ultimately pointless since we‚Äôll never get answers in this life?"

Check out my previous videos with Dr. Mullins listed below:

title: How did God Influence the Authors of the Bible? (Dr. Stephen Davis)
description:
I am joined by Dr. Stephen Davis to summarize his essay on Revelation and Inspiration in the Oxford Handbook of Philosophical Theology.

Stephen T. Davis (PhD, Claremont Graduate University) is the Russell K. Pitzer Professor of Philosophy at Claremont McKenna College. He specializes in the philosophy of religion and Christian thought, and he is the author or editor of over fifteen books including Encountering Evil, Christian Philosophical Theology, and Disputed Issues. He has also written more than seventy academic articles and reviews. In 2015, he was honored with the festschrift Christian Philosophy of Religion: Essays in Honor of Stephen T. Davis.

title: 3 Responses to this Common Objection to the Kalam (Dr. Josh Rasmussen)
description:
00:00 Introduction

00:27 Objection to Premise 1 of Kalam Cosmological Argument

01:17 Kalam Cosmological Argument

02:57 Description of Mereological nihilism

04:50 Undercutting defeater vs. rebutting defeater

05:51 First response

09:04 Second response

12:14 Third response

This week's question is, "Are eliminitivist views of material constitution (e.g. mereological nihilism) compatible with inductive arguments supporting the first premise of some formulation of the Kalam Cosmological Argument? There seems to be less inductive support for 'whatever begins to exist has a cause' if there is never a case of something coming to exist by way of an arrangement of particles. Most of our examples of something coming to exist with a cause are things coming into existence by way of arrangements of particles. What do you think?"

My guest is Dr. Josh Rasmussen, a professor of philosophy at Asuza Pacific University.

Link to Josh's article on this topic:
https://joshualrasmussen.com/does-every-beginning-have-a-cause.html

Please consider becoming one of my patrons. Just go to https://www.patreon.com/theanalyticchristian

title: God & Puzzles from Infinity (Dr. Daniel Rubio)
description:
"Ask A Scholar" is a new project I'm starting where you can get your questions answered by a scholar. To participate go to www.patreon.com/ccapologetics, and sign up for Level 2 or Level 3.

This week's question was, "Can God count to infinity twice? If He can, does that mean the number of past events could be infinite? If He can't, how can he have the foreknowledge of an infinite future (or, at least, of an infinite possible future)?"

Dr. Daniel Rubio is a professor of philosophy at Princeton University. To find out more about Dr. Rubio's work check out the link below.

title: The Puzzle of Prayer And God's Foreknowledge (Dr. Scott Davison)
description:
"Ask A Scholar" is a new project I'm starting where you can get your questions answered by a scholar. To participate go to www.patreon.com/ccapologetics, and sign up for Level 2 or Level 3.

This week's question was, "There are a few stories in the bible that appear as if we can change God's mind. I understand God as the Maximally Great Being who knows the beginning from the end. Does this mean that no matter what we cannot change his mind, maybe from prayer, because he already knows the end? Or has he already factored in every prayer from every person at every time as though it would seem that we have the ability to change his mind?"

Dr. Scott Davison is a professor of philosophy at Morehead State University. To find out more about Dr. Davison's work check out the link below.
https://www.moreheadstate.edu/Caudill-College-of-Arts,-Humanities-and-Social-Sci/History,-Philosophy,-International-Studies-and-Leg/Faculty-and-Staff/Davison,-Scott

title: Answering An Objection to Molinism (Justin Mooney)
description:
Before the creation of the world, did God know what I would do if he placed me in various circumstances? Molinists think the answer is yes. But how can God have that kind of knowledge explanatorily prior to creation? If a molinist replies, "God is omniscient, so he just knows. Don't ask!" that just doesn't seem sufficient. I am joined by Justin Mooney, a Ph.D. student in philosophy at the University of Massachusetts. We will be discussing his paper, "How God Knows Counterfactuals of Freedom" published in the journal Faith and Philosophy. 

Link to paper

title: Moral Authority & Normative Reasons (Dr. Eric Sampson)
description:
"Ask A Scholar" is a new project I'm starting where you can get your questions answered by a scholar. To participate go to www.patreon.com/ccapologetics, and sign up for Level 2 or Level 3.

This week's question was, "What makes a moral norm authoritative? What makes a moral norm authoritative? The question reveals a bootstrapping problem for morality. A moral norm P can only be authoritative if there is some external (prior) authoritative norm Q, that makes norm P authoritative. But then we can ask what makes norm Q authoritative? And this can continue ad infinitum. It's an analogous problem to what's known as the prior obligation objection to Divine Command Theory. Have any thoughts on grounding moral authority?"

Dr. Eric Sampson is a professor of philosophy at Georgetown University. To find out more about Dr. Sampson's work check out the link below.
http://www.erictsampson.com/

I am joined by Dr. Travis Dumsday to discuss his paper, "Evidentially Compelling Religious Experiences and the Moral Status of Naturalism." Dr. Dumsday is a professor of philosophy at Concordia University of Edmonton. The link to his paper is below. In the paper he presents several published cases of evidentially compelling religious experiences (ECREs), then argues that given the commonality of testimony to experiences like these, naturalists are faced with a dilemma of immorality or irrationality. Lastly, he defends his argument against several objections.

title: Is Free Will Compatible with God's Omniscience? (Dr. Taylor Cyr)
description:
00:00-3:22 Introduction
3:23-4:43 what do we mean by ‚ÄòGod‚Äô?
4:44-5:55 what is it for God to be eternal?
5:55-7:00 what is it for God to be essentially omniscient?
7:01-9:00 what is free will?
9:01-9:43 What‚Äôs the general idea about why free will and divine foreknowledge are incompatible?
9:43-12:09 What is the main argument for the incompatibility of free will and divine foreknowledge?
12:10-12:56 What is it to have a choice about something?
12:57-14:07 How does the main argument generalize to other actions?
14:07-17:13 Is the argument valid?  What is validity?
17:14-18:34 Is the premise plausible that we don‚Äôt have a choice about what God believes a thousand years ago?  What is the fixity of the past?
18:35-19:57 Does the argument involve backward causation?
19:57-22:00 Is the second premise (that God‚Äôs believing X will occur entails that X will occur) of the main argument plausible? 
22:01-25:35 Can we say that since human foreknowledge allows free will, so does divine free will?  How are human foreknowledge and divine foreknowledge different?
25:35-29:45 Why isn‚Äôt Molinism a solution to the problem of divine foreknowledge and free will?
29:46-30:43 What are, broadly, the compatibilist and incompatibilist responses to the main argument?
30:44-31:32 How are the terms ‚Äòcompatibilism‚Äô and incompatibilism‚Äô used in different ways?
31:33-34:09 What is the timelessness response to the main argument?
34:10-36:45 Why does the timelessness response not sufficiently deal with the puzzle?  How can we revise the main argument to avoid the timelessness response?
36:45-38:52 How is there an analogue of the fixity of the past principle in a revised version of the main argument (designed to deal with the timelessness response?)
38:52-43:00 What is Ockhamism?  What is the difference between hard and soft facts?
43:01-44:20 How does Ockhamism apply to the main argument?
44:21-48:08 What is the first problem with the Ockhamist response?  
48:09-50:28 What is the second problem with the Ockhamist response?
50:28-55:58 What is the Dependence view?
55:59-59:29 What is an objection to the Dependence view?
59:30-59:46 What are the incompatibilist responses?
59:47-1:02:06 What is open theism?
1:02:07-1:04:10 Which premise does the open theist attack?
1:04:11-1:05:24 How is free will relevant to the problem of evil?
1:05:25-1:06:35 Does the open theist give up the view that God is omniscient?
1:06:35-1:08:35 What are the two versions of open theism: open futurism and limited foreknowledge?
1:08:36-1:10:54 Does God have a mechanism for knowing?  How does God know what he knows?
1:10:55-1:12:56 What are some objections to open theism?
1:12:57-1:14:30 What is the semi-compatibilism?
1:14:30-1:18:30 What are Frankfurt counterexamples and how do they support semi-compatibilism?
1:18:31-1:20:52 What is PAP (the principle of alternative possibilities)?
1:20:53-1:23:30 What is an objection to semi-compatibilism?
1:23:30-1:27:00 What‚Äôs an overall summary of the discussion?
1:27:01-1:27:37 Why do Dr. Cyr and Jordan Hampton look like nemeses?
1:27:38-1:34:07 Does God have the ability to do otherwise?
1:34:08-1:37:35 Why do you prefer semi-compatibilism to source libertarianism?
1:37:36-1:40:11 If God knows the future, then can God be free?
1:40:12-1:41:58 How, on Molinism, can there be alternate possibilities in specific circumstances?
1:41:59-1:45:27 Why not be a presentist?  Doesn‚Äôt eternalism lead to a weird view of persons?
1:45:27-1:49:01 Is Dr. Cyr reformed?


Theists are faced with a puzzle. If God's foreknows that I will do something  before I do it, then is it the case that I must do that thing? And If I must do that thing, am I really free? 

In this interview, Dr. Taylor Cyr (pronounced "seer") joins me to discuss various solutions to this puzzle. He is a philosophy professor at Samford University. For more information, check out his website linked below.

https://taylorwcyr.com/

title: Assessing Evolutionary Debunking Arguments (Dr. Tomas Bogardus)
description:
In this interview, Dr. Tomas Bogardus joins me to discuss his paper "Only All Naturalists Should Worry About Only One Evolutionary Debunking Argument." The pdf of the paper is linked below. In the paper, he presents three versions of evolutionary debunking arguments (EDA's) against moral knowledge and shows why each fails. He then presents a fourth version of an EDA that is successful, but explains why it should only concern naturalists.

https://philpapers.org/archive/BOGOAN.pdf

title: Three Inspiring Individuals Who Said Yes to God (Interview with Dr. Michael Rota)
description:
In the final video of this playlist on Pascal's Wager, Dr. Michael Rota tells the stories of Dietrich Bonhoeffer, Jean Vanier, and Immaculee Ilibagiza. These individuals lived a devout Christian life at great cost. Despite the losses, their lives were enriched, and enriched many others. After hearing these stories, I suspect you will feel inspired to live a life like that, showing that a life of Christian commitment is desirable.

We wrap up by saying that if Christianity is both reasonable (as videos 5-11 demonstrated) and desirable (as this video demonstrated) then one should take the Wager (as videos 1-4 demonstrated). Rota then lays out some specific practical steps if you decide to take the Wager.

Link to Rota's book:
https://www.amazon.com/Taking-Pascals-Wager-Evidence-Abundant/dp/0830851364/ref=sr_1_1?crid=10OXLLAZ5ON4O&dchild=1&keywords=taking+pascal%27s+wager+faith%2C+evidence+and+the+abundant+life&qid=1591038111&sprefix=taking+pascal%27s+wager%2Caps%2C167&sr=8-1

Link to the playlist:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLlVH-ThCazKlqtTVa-3hvKfBXy5LajVsw

title: 10yr Old Answers Deep Questions About Life
description:
My 10 year old nephew loves watching my videos.  So I thought it would be fun to bring him on and get his thoughts on some of the big questions and thought experiments in philosophy .

What is philosophy?
Does God exist? How do you know?
Why are we here? What is the purpose of life?
What happens after we die?
What are thoughts?
Is it always wrong to lie? When (if ever) is it okay?
What‚Äôs your answer to the trolley problem?

title: Cosmic Skeptic vs. Liz Jackson on Pascal's Wager (Infinity vs. Intuition)
description:
In a recent debate on Capturing Christianity's YouTube Channel (see the link below) Alex O'Connor made several objections to Liz Jackson's updated version of Pascal's Wager. His major objection though, was  that Liz's version of the Wager faces a serious dilemma. EITHER she must accept her intuition and give up the use of infinity in her decision matrix, OR accept the use of infinity in her decision matrix, and give up her intuition. Both alternatives end in failure.

Liz and I discuss this objection in detail, and comment on some of the other objections Alex raised as well.

Link to the Original Debate:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tv4jE2TUEGY&t=1439s

title: A Defense of Reformed Epistemology (Interview with Dr. Andrew Moon)
description:
0:00 Introduction

5:58-8:43 Evidentialist Objection
9:25-15:17 De Jure vs. De Facto Distinction

17:15-24:26 Basic vs. Properly Basic Belief
26:13-27:31 What is it for a belief to be justified?

29:08-30:39 What is warrant?

35:45-36:36 What is Plantinga's argument that belief in God is warranted if God exists?
36:36-41:15 What does Plantinga's argument achieve?

1:35:03-1:37:11 Does Reformed Epistemology rely on how good the arguments are for what God desires?
1:37:33-1:41:03 Does the existence of atheists show that God doesn't want to be known?
1:41:21-1:42:37 What is the strongest objection to Reformed Epistemology?
1:42:38-1:43:08 If the rationality of belief in the good is based on a God-given feeling, does that mean that non-believers can't recognize it?

Dr. Andrew Moon is a Professor of Philosophy at Virginia Commonwealth University. In this interview we discuss his paper "Recent Work in Reformed Epistemology" published by the journal Philosophy Compass in 2016.

https://capturingchristianity.com/the-great-pumpkin-objection-to-reformed-epistemology/

title: Critiquing Arguments for Moral Nihilism (Interview with Eric Sampson)
description:
The moral error theorist does not believe in such things as moral values and moral obligations. John Mackie offered two arguments for this view that have come to be held with high regard among moral nihilists. The first is the argument from disagreement. The second is the argument from queerness. In this interview, Eric Sampson critiques both arguments.

Eric Sampson is a Ph.D. candidate at the University of North Carolina Chapel Hill. The two papers linked below are the topic of this interview.

https://philpapers.org/rec/SAMTSA-6

https://philpapers.org/rec/MORPAT-23

title: Why God's Triune Nature is the Foundation of Morality (Interview with Adam Johnson)
description:
In a previous interview I did with Adam Johnson, he critiqued Dr. Eric Weilenberg's metaethical model. In this interview he defends his own model, which is a new and distinctively Christian.

Link to my previous interview with Adam
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fs_t0zJUoB8

title: Critiquing Dr. Erik Wielenberg's Metaethical Model (Interview with Adam Johnson)
description:
Adam Lloyd Johnson is a PhD candidate at Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary specializing in metaethics. He teaches philosophy at Theologisches Seminar Rhineland in W√∂lmerson, Germany. He is also a campus missionary with Ratio Christi.

In 2015 he published a paper in the journal Philosophia Christi titled, Debunking Nontheistic Moral Realism: A Critique of Eric Wielenberg's Attempt to Deflect the Lucky Coincidence Objection. The paper is linked below. Adam summarizes the paper in this interview.

https://www.pdcnet.org/pc/content/pc_2015_0017_0002_0353_0367

title: Assessing Various Forms of the Ontological Argument
description: Dr. Tyron Goldschmidt is Assistant Professor of Philosophy at Rochester University. His book on Ontological Arguments will soon be published by Cambridge University Press. Dr. Goldschmidt is my first non-Christian guest. He is Jewish. He also thinks Ontological Arguments are interesting but ultimately do not succeed. In the future I will try to bring on a guest who thinks the ontological argument is successful.

title: Answering Three Contemporary Challenges to the Historical Case for the Resurrection of Jesus
description:
In a recent book- Jesus, Skepticism & the Problem of History, Dr. Mike Licona contributed an essay titled, "Jesus' Resurrection, Realism, and the Role of the Criteria of Authenticity." In it, he addresses the following three objections:
1) historians don't have the proper tools to investigate an event that is miraculous in nature.
2) historians don't have the ability to learn about the past.
3) historians "criteria of authenticity" is not effective.

In this interview, Dr. Licona answers these three objections.

Link to the book: https://www.amazon.com/Jesus-Skepticism-Problem-History-Christian/dp/0310534763/ref=sr_1_1?crid=2HQ0A6PYVT0YG&keywords=jesus+skepticism+and+the+problem+of+history&qid=1580942159&s=books&sprefix=jesus+skepticism%2Caps%2C168&sr=1-1

title: A NEW Moral Argument for the Christian God
description:
Dr. Bobby Conway runs an apologetics YouTube ministry called the one minute apologist. He is currently a doctoral candidate at the University of Birmingham. The topic of his dissertation is a moral argument for the existence of the Christian God from the existence of objective guilt. The link to his channel is below along with a livestream he did outlining some of the major points of his argument. You should definitely subscribe to his channel!

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXkgIl5W-HXG8-srQdyAbDw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IDTNjCdDzag

title: How Pascal's Wager Explains Divine Hiddenness
description:
In this interview, I am joined by Dr. Liz Jackson to discuss her paper "Wagering Against Divine Hiddenness." The link is below. She critiques John Schellenberg's argument against the existence of God:

S1: If God exists, he is perfectly loving.
S2: If a perfectly loving God exists, then non-resistant non-belief does not occur.
S3: Non-resistant non-belief occurs.
S4: No perfectly loving God exists (from S2, S3).
S5: Therefore God does not exist (from S1, S4).

Liz's paper: https://philpapers.org/rec/ELIWAD

My previous interview with Liz: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e6qHRLkFhCM&t=2197s

My previous interview on the topic of Divine Hiddenness:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EsMEnxuApks&t=1599s

title: An Abductive Moral Argument for a Good God (Interview with Dr. David Baggett)
description:
Dr. David Baggett earned his Ph.D from Wayne State University and he is currently professor of philosophy at Liberty University School of Divinity. There are various moral arguments for the existence of God, but Dr. Baggett's is intriguing because his moral argument uniquely combines the others in a way that points specifically to the Christian God. If this interests you, check out his book called "The Morals of the Story: Good News About a Good God" published by IVP in 2018. This link is below.

https://www.amazon.com/Morals-Story-Good-News-About/dp/0830852077/ref=sr_1_1?keywords=the+morals+of+the+story&qid=1576635917&sr=8-1

He runs an awesome website devoted to moral apologetics linked below. If you are interested in this interview, and the others I've done on morality, you must check it out!
https://www.moralapologetics.com/

title: Answering Classic and Contemporary Objections (Interview with Dr. Matthew Flannagan)
description:
Dr. Matthew Flannagan earned his Ph.D from the University of Otago. He currently resides in Auckland New Zealand where he teaches ethics at St. Peters College in Epsom. Our discussion is based on chapters 12-14 of the book "Did God Really Command Genocide" which Matthew co-wrote with Dr. Paul Copan. The link to the book is at the bottom of this description. In this interview, he lays out what Divine Command Theory is and is not. He then responds to the following types of objections:

1) Arbitrariness/No Reasons Objections
2) Omnipotence Objection
3) Counterfactual Objection
4) Wielenberg's Psychopathy Objection
5) Emptiness Objection to God's Goodness

https://www.amazon.com/Did-God-Really-Command-Genocide/dp/0801016223

title: Answering Scientific Challenges to the Universe's Origin (Interview with Dr. Jeff Zweerink)
description:
Astrophysicist Jeff Zweerink is a research scholar at Reasons to Believe and a Project Scientist at UCLA. He earned a PhD in astrophysics from Iowa State University. He is the author of several books including Escaping the Beginning: Confronting Challenges to the Universe's Origin. The link is below.

In this interview Dr. Zweerink critiques the most prevalent eternal universe theories and argues in favor of a beginning.

https://www.amazon.com/Escaping-Beginning-Confronting-Challenges-Universes-ebook/dp/B07XDMZFRB/ref=sr_1_1_sspa?crid=1LTWEPBP5LYTC&keywords=escaping+the+beginning&qid=1575139805&sprefix=escaping+the+begin%2Caps%2C584&sr=8-1-spons&psc=1&spLa=ZW5jcnlwdGVkUXVhbGlmaWVyPUExRU1UM0JRV1o3MjhGJmVuY3J5cHRlZElkPUEwOTE1MDI1MVc3RVlXR0VZWTEyQSZlbmNyeXB0ZWRBZElkPUEwOTgzNDI1MUtQSTRYS1JOM1VSJndpZGdldE5hbWU9c3BfYXRmJmFjdGlvbj1jbGlja1JlZGlyZWN0JmRvTm90TG9nQ2xpY2s9dHJ1ZQ==

description:

He's published two books (The Normative Web, and Speech and Morality) with Oxford University Press arguing for moral realism. The link to both books are shown below. In this interview he summarizes those arguments and offers responses to objections against moral realism.

title: The Divine Council, Cosmic Conflict, and the Problem of Evil (Interview with Dr. John Peckham)
description:
Dr. John Peckham is professor of Theology and Christian Philosophy at the Seminary of Andrews University. In 2018, Peckham published his book Theodicy of Love where he offers a biblically based model for understanding why an omnipotent, omniscient, omnibenevolent God allows suffering and evil. I found this book to be both profound and practical in its insight. In the words of Paul Copan, "it fills an important gap in the literature addressing the problem of evil." The link to the book can be found below.

description:

description:

title: Pascal's Wager- A Conversation with Kurt Jaros of Veracity Hill
description:
Kurt Jaros invited me on Veracity Hill to discuss Pascal's Wager with him. In this video I offer some background on Pascal and the Wager. I then present the updated argument, along with some helpful ways of illustrating it in conversation. We then answer some popular objections at the end of the program. The conversation actually begins at 4:30

 After the show he invited me to begin blogging for Apologetics 315 on Wednesdays. My first two posts give a simple, easy to remember way of presenting Pascal's Wager in conversation. If that interests you, check out the link to part 1 and part 2 below.

title: Exploring a New Contingency Argument (Interview with Dr. Joshua Rasmussen)
description:
Dr. Joshua Rasmussen is an assistant professor of philosophy at Azusa Pacific University, and has published a new book "How Reason Can Lead to God: A Philosopher's Bridge to Faith." In it, he invites the skeptic to explore and test with him each step that led him to discover ultimate foundation of reality and greatest treasure- God.

Here is the link to the book.
https://www.amazon.com/How-Reason-Can-Lead-God/dp/0830852522

For more on Dr. Rasmussen:
https://www.apu.edu/theology/faculty/jrasmussen/

title: Answering the Most Challenging Objections to the Wager (Interview with Dr. Liz Jackson)
description:
Pascal's Wager has come under a lot of fire- the "many-gods" objection, the "mixed strategy" objection, and several others are examples. Recently,  Dr. Elizabeth Jackson and Dr. Andrew Rogers published an article in Philosophia Christi addressing the most challenging objections. I am joined by Dr. Jackson to discuss this article. If you are interested in the Wager, or have your objections to it, watch and enjoy. You won't be disappointed.

Here is the link to Liz's article. 
https://philpapers.org/rec/JACSPW 

Here is a link to Liz's website.
http://liz-jackson.com/ 

Here is the link to my playlist on Pascal's Wager
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLlVH-ThCazKlqtTVa-3hvKfBXy5LajVsw

title: A Bayesian Fine-Tuning Argument (#7)
description:
In this video I explain what Fine-Tuning means and how it points to God. This argument is different from other arguments from Fine-Tuning in that it uses Bayes' Theorem to weigh the evidence. By the end you see that even if you think there probably isn't a God, once you factor in the fine-tuning evidence, the probability of a necessary being who designed the universe for life is really high. The argument presented in the video is a summary from Michael Rota's book, "Taking Pascal's Wager" pages 99-124.

Here is the link to Rota's book: 
https://www.amazon.com/Taking-Pascals-Wager-Evidence-Abundant/dp/0830851364/ref=sr_1_1?keywords=taking+pascal%27s+wager&qid=1567205815&s=gateway&sr=8-1 

Check out more videos in this playlist:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLlVH-ThCazKlqtTVa-3hvKfBXy5LajVsw

Music https://www.bensound.com

title: Answering the Problem of Divine Hiddenness (Interview with Blake Giunta)
description:
The problem of Divine Hiddenness is an argument against the existence of God formalized by the philosopher J. L. Schellenberg. In this interview, Apologist Blake Giunta presents the argument and we discuss how Theists, and Christian Theists in particular can respond. 

Blake runs a website called beliefmap.org which is a fun, rigorous, and intuitive way explore the arguments and counterarguments that come up in conversations about the big questions: Does God exist? Did Jesus rise from the dead? Can I know God personally?

To see Blake's response to the problem of divine hiddenness in greater detail check out the link below:
https://beliefmap.org/god-exists/divine-hiddenness/

If you enjoy this video and the content of this channel, please consider subscribing. I greatly appreciate your interest and support!

title: Bayes' Theorem for Beginners (#6)
description:
In this video I explain how to weigh evidence in general using Bayes' Theorem, so that you will know how to weigh the fine-tuning evidence for God. This video explains how Bayes' Theorem works, so that you'll understand the Bayesian version of the fine-tuning argument I'll present in my next video. This introduction is my summary of Michael Rota's book, Taking Pascal's Wager pages 113-118. The link is below.

https://www.amazon.com/Taking-Pascals-Wager-Evidence-Abundant/dp/0830851364

The argument I summarize in this video comes from Michael Rota's book "Taking Pascal's Wager," pages 83-98. To purchase the book, see the link below. title: Pascal's Wager Not Debunked (#4): Answering the Top 5 Objections
description:
In this video, I answer what I think are the top 5 objections to Pascal's Wager.
1) You can't force yourself to believe in God
2) Pascal's reasoning leads to absurdities
3) Pascal's Wager is immoral
4) The cost of commitment is just too high
5) Pascal's Wager ignores other gods/religions

Please watch the whole video and comment below if you have another objection to Pascal's Wager that you would like me to address.

Michael Rota covers additional objections in his book "Taking Pascal's Wager" so definitely purchase a copy for more.
https://www.amazon.com/Taking-Pascals-Wager-Evidence-Abundant/dp/0830851364

title: Pascal's Wager Not Debunked (#3): Basic Argument
description:
In this video, I explain the basic version of Pascal's Updated Wager offered by Dr. Michael Rota in his book "Taking Pascal's Wager."  My next video will include the extended version of the argument and answer objections frequently raised.

To watch the other videos in this playlist:

title: Pascal's Wager Not Debunked (#2): Decision Theory
description:
In order to understand Michael Rota's updated version of Pascal's Wager, we first need to get acquainted with the basic concepts of Decision Theory. In this video we see some examples that help illustrate two guiding principles. These principles can be used to make good decisions in circumstances of risk or uncertainty.

See link below for Michael Rota's book "Taking Pascal's Wager"

title: Pascal's Wager Not Debunked (#1): Introduction
description:
YouTube is full of atheists claiming to have debunked Pascal's Wager.  They are ignoring the most rigorous updated form of the argument, recently put forward by Dr. Michael Rota in his book Taking Pascal's Wager. I'll be summarizing the book one chapter at a time and putting the videos in a playlist.

title: R.O.S.E.S.- Eternal Life
description: Dr. Kenneth Keathley has provided a Molinist perspective on the doctrine of salvation in his book Salvation & Sovereignty. Keathley uses the acronym R.O.S.E.S. to focus on key tenants of a Molinist Soteriology, much as T.U.L.I.P. summarizes a Calvinist Soteriology. In this video, I focus on the "E" in Roses, which stands for Eternal Life. This sub doctrine takes up the issue of eternal security and perseverance of the saints. For a more detailed treatment of specific passages in scripture check out my blog linked here: https://hampton45.wixsite.com/findingfaith/single-post/2018/06/27/The-E-in-ROSES-A-Molinist-Soteriology
